questions.question_text: Which of the following implements a stream cipher?

discussion.content:
C is correct. SFTP utilizes the SSH. There are various ciphers the SSH server can use to perform encryption and decryption functions. RC4 is among one of them, and it is a stream cipher.

Reference: https://www.juniper.net/documentation/en_US/junos/topics/reference/configuration-statement/system-edit-ssh-ciphers.html

S/MIME uses DSS for digital signature, and DH or RSA for key exchange, and 3DES (which is a symmetric block algorithm) for message encryption; I found nothing that supports the possibility to choose a stream cipher algorithm for message encryption, instead of 3DES.

SFTP uses Diffie-Hellman for the key exchange; after that, the encryption is done using a symmetric algorithms, selected among a wide choice of possible algorithms, most of which are block chipers; anyway, among all the possible chipers that can be selected, there is ALSO arcfour (that is RC4, Rivest chiper 4) which is a stream chiper. So SFTP might be the right answer. (https://www.jscape.com/blog/setting-sftp-algorithms)

YES S/MIME IS THE ANSWER
because S/MIME uses AES for symmetric and RC4 for Asymmetric encryption

comments.content: AES uses BLOCK ciphers

discussion.content:
C is my choice: Secure file transfer protocols like SFTP, FTPS, and HTTPS encrypt data through symmetric key ciphers.
RC4 is a symmetric algorithm that encrypts with a stream cipher.
I have found on other webpages it is C. https://www.coursehero.com/file/42872686/Newestdocx/
Answer is C. SFTP implements RC4 as a stream cipher, but it usually disabled by default. https://zappysys.com/forums/topic/ciphers-algorithms-supported-sftp-connection/

Guys, its not SMIME since mine does not have implementation for stream Cipher. Its SFTP which uses SSH. SSH uses TLS/SSL at layer 6 of OSI. TLS 1.2 includes ChaCha20, Poly1305 and RC4 which are stream ciphers. So by my understanding C should be considered correct. 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transport_Layer_Security

In my studies I have found that S/MIME uses PKI along with a hybrid encryption method of RSA and AES, nothing I have learned suggests it uses stream ciphers.

IKEv2 uses all block cipher modes:
https://www.vocal.com/secure-communication/internet-key-exchange-v-2/

Other sources say that stream ciphers are best used for small amounts of data, usually less than 64 bits. Are best implemented in hardware because the data size makes it infeasible to have enough RAM or CPU cycles to process the data. RC4 is the most frequently used implementation and is commonly used with WEP and SSL.

comments.content: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3686

discussion.content:
Another whacked question from CompTIA. The only answer I could find that supports a stream cipher is SFTP (which makes sense as a stream cipher is good at encrypting data in transit). So I believe the correct answer should be 'C'.

FYI: There was a cursory note that IKEv2 can use stream ciphers under certain conditions, but it was an obscure reference which I'm perfectly willing to ignore. :)
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4253

Nop! Can't figure this one out.
Another tosser gents - have at it...
The ans is shown C on coursehero.
It would be strange if to have stream cipher for emails. I would go with SFTP

S/MIME encrypts the message by using a symmetric cipher whose key is protected using the recipient's public key. Asymmetric cryptography has too high a performance overhead to be used for encrypting messages, so messages are encrypted using symmetric cryptography, with asymmetric cryptography used to protect the secret key. A stream cipher is a type of symmetric encryption algorithm.
https://www.isode.com/whitepapers/smime-military-messaging.html

SFTP probably

https://www.jscape.com/blog/stream-cipher-vs-block-cipher

S/MIME uses AES for encryption. AES uses block cipher. 
So the answer wouldn't be D.

comments.content: Don’t forget, AES has many modes of operation at least one of which is a stream cipher
Which mode...place cite this source! I will probably go with D since I fell I eliminated the rest but you wanna state it as fact about AES stream mode, at least you could c/p a source!!!

Well, S/MIME incorporates three public-key algorithms, DSS for digital sigantures, Diffie-Hellman for encyrpting session keys, or RSA. It uses SHA1 or MD5 for calculating digests, and three-key triple DES for message encryption. ADDITIONALLY, WHEN GOOGLING STREAM CIPHERS, RC4 is the only hit of 18 different stream ciphers. BUT a google of SSH, so far hasn't mentioned RC4

Seems SSH can use RC4 - optionally
RC4-based protocols
WEP
WPA (default algorithm, but can be configured to use AES-CCMP instead of RC4)
BitTorrent protocol encryption
Microsoft Office XP (insecure implementation since nonce remains unchanged when documents get modified[64])
Microsoft Point-to-Point Encryption
Transport Layer Security / Secure Sockets Layer (was optional and then the use of RC4 was prohibited in RFC 7465)
Secure Shell (optionally)
Remote Desktop Protocol (optionally)
Kerberos (optionally)
SASL Mechanism Digest-MD5 (optionally, historic, obsoleted in RFC 6331
Ill go with SFTP!!! Sorry to take up all this space!

I think I found it!!!
https://code.activestate.com/recipes/577090-file-encryption-using-stream-cipher/
ANSWER IS A!!!!

In a rebuttal to a comment below, this link has 1 mention of "stream cipher" and the sentence says "unlike stream, block ciphers..."
https://cybernews.com/resources/what-is-aes-encryption/
So my delving shows no instance of AES having a stream mode...so if D is correct, it isnt because it uses any sort of AES "stream cipher" I have done all I can with this question, and notsure what else can be done!! will flag this question and check back to see if I can be refuted!

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stream_cipher will show you only RC4 and this link, I believe rules out SFTP
https://www.jscape.com/blog/setting-sftp-algorithms#:~:text=That%27s%20why%20SFTP%20file%20transfer%20is%20very%20suitable,algorithms%20used%20for%20this%20purpose%20are%20called%20ciphers. 
I also deep dove into file level encryption and saw no mention of stream ciphers!!!

SORRY FOR ALL THE COMMENTS! I was honestly trying to help...lesson learned! When I got to Question 255, I had a thought and rephrased my question to google and found that file level encryption uses stream ciphers! 
https://code.activestate.com/recipes/577090-file-encryption-using-stream-cipher/

discussion.content: I can't find anything saying D is right, but A-C are all wrong.

questions.question_text: A security technician has been assigned data destruction duties. The hard drives that are being disposed of contain highly sensitive information. Which of the following data destruction techniques is MOST appropriate?

discussion.content: Shredding is more secure than deguassing since the actual drives are physically destroyed.

comments.content: The actual term for shredding hard drive is pulverizing not shredding. If they meant shredding, Comptia should have included the term pulverizing in the option rather than using degaussing and shredding

That is incorrect at least according to the newest Comptia book. 
Shredding and pulping—most media can be shredded. For paper documents, shredders are rated by the size of the remnants they reduce a sheet to. Level 1 is 12mm strips, while Level 6 is 0.8x4mm particles. Pulping the shredded remains with water or incinerating them provides an extra measure of protection. Some office shredders can destroy optical media too. Industrial shredders can destroy hard drives and flash drives.

Pulverizing—hitting a hard drive with a hammer can leave a surprising amount of recoverable data, so this type of destruction should be performed with industrial machinery.

discussion.content:
Degaussing :
Pros: A degausser is good if you want to completely erase all audio, video and data signals from the magnetic storage.

Cons: Degaussing is not entirely fool-proof. It can only be used on magnetic media, and there is no way to guarantee that a particular degaussing machine is strong enough to destroy all the data on every hard drive. Also, degaussing does not provide reporting of the erasure process, which is needed to prove regulatory compliance. Most IT professionals will tell you that degaussing or wiping hard drives is no longer an acceptable method for complete, secure destruction of stored data.
___
Benefits of Hard Drive Shredding:

Your sensitive data is now 100% unrecoverable, so you don’t have to worry at all about hackers seizing your data.
You can ensure your business is in compliance with regulatory requirements, avoiding fines and potential lawsuits.
For personal computers, your data will be safely destroyed without the worry of identity theft
___
We can use degaussing, hard drives are HDD, not SSD, but shredding is better
Comparison:
https://legalshred.com/degaussing-vs-hard-drive-shredding/

Confidential or secret documents should be marked as such. Such documents may be treated to special disposal methods, such as finer cross-shredding or even incineration. There are several types of shredders. They can be classified to a certain security level, based on the size of the remnants they reduce a sheet to. Level 1 is 12mm strips, while Level 6 is 0.8x4mm particles.

If shredding is not considered secure enough, the shredded material can be further subjected to a process of pulping (mixing with water then pulverizing) or burning.

I guess if you can shred HHD- Next best answer after looking at Darril Gibson book would be degaussing - "A degausser is very powerful electronic magnet. Passing disk through field renders the data on tape and magnetic disk drives unreadable'
Which of the following data destruction techniques is MOST appropriate?
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZW632ogPeRA&list=PLG49S3nxzAnnVhoAaL4B6aMFDQ8_gdxAy&index=115

"According to many in the information security field, including the US National Security Agency (NSA), shredding of HDDs is not the best method of destroying information contained in the drive. Degaussing is by far the most common method of sanitizing Top Secret data."
According to many in the information security field, including the US National Security Agency (NSA), shredding of HDDs is not the best method of destroying information contained in the drive. ... Degaussing is by far the most common method of sanitizing Top Secret data.
https://www.intimus.com/resources/white-papers/best-practices-destroying-hard-disk-drives-shredding-vs-degaussing/
We dont known if the disk is SSD or HDD. You cant degause SSD disks. It wouldnt work. So the answer has to be Shredding.

comments.content:
HDD: Hard Disk Drive

SSD: Solid-state drive

discussion.content:
Other resource:
Answer: A
Explanation:
Hard drive degaussing is a highly advanced technology used to sanitize hard drives before 
disposal or reuse. Degaussers come in various types and sizes, with varying effectiveness as 
well. A professional data destruction service selects the most appropriate degausser for the job 
based on prevailing circumstances.
Degaussing is fast and effective, and it ensures that you're compliant with data regulations.

It appears that according to Comptia GCGA book that shredding is never referenced to hard drives it is only referenced for paper. So when taking this specific test, pulverizing is physically destroying drives and shredding is shredding paper. So that answer is A actually from what i can tell...

Degaussing--> Degaussing is not entirely fool-proof. It can only be used on magnetic media, and there is no way to guarantee that a particular degaussing machine is strong enough to destroy all the data on every hard drive.

Shredding--> The best and most secure method of rendering hard drive information completely unusable is to completely destroy it through hard drive shredding, your sensitive data is now 100% unrecoverable.

So, D. is the correct answer.

Reference: https://legalshred.com/degaussing-vs-hard-drive-shredding/
A is the correct answer. Why? the keyword is "data destruction" not hard drives
Pulverize = reduce to fine particles = Shred = destroy

comments.content: If the term hard drive shredding is popular in the industry, I'm wondering why comptia does not differentiate between pulverizing and hard drive shredding. They should have stick to one term or merge both as pulverizing/hard drive shredding

discussion.content: A is the correct answer. You cannot reuse a hard drive once it has been degaussed. This is because the degaussing process removes all the data and start up files. As such, a degaussed hard drive will not boot up.

comments.content: Shredding is correct. If they were asking for most TIME EFFECIENT, it would be degaussing.

So the correct answer should have been pulverising not shredding. You pulverise hard drive, shred papers. Since pulverising is not an option and the question has to do with sanitizing hard drive, the correct answer should have been degaussing.
How I wish the moderators are putting up correct answers (with explanation) and not just assumed answers

I've seen refrigerators shredded. Trust me, Hard Drives with sensitive data can and should be shredded.

questions.question_text: Which of the following BEST explains how the use of configuration templates reduces organization risk?

discussion.content: Took the exam today & passed. However I would like to ask everyone that not to depend only on these questions . Just like everyone mentioned go through the discussion and understand why the answers are correct. I only had a handful of questions(including one PBQ) from here but knowing material helped me to pass the exam.

comments.content: Thank you for your help

A is correct. A template contains all the secure design you want your systems to have. By using that template for configuration, it ensure you do not miss out on any part of your secure baseline configuration
he gives us good tips, tips are always welcome.

Congrats for passing the exam, but if you don't bring any input here, better abstain.
Anyways, I think the correct answer is B, not A.
What material have you used ? Darril Gibson doesn't have all the knowledge to answer in his book
Gibson's book and the these practice questions should be good enough to pass the exam.

choices.B: It enables system rollback to a last known-good state if patches break functionality.
choices.C: It facilitates fault tolerance since applications can be migrated across templates.
choices.A: It ensures consistency of configuration for initial system implementation.
choices.D: It improves vulnerability scanning efficiency across multiple systems.

questions.question_text:
A Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) is performing a BIA for the organization in case of a natural disaster. Which of the following should be at the top of the
CISO's list?

choices.D: Identity the impact on safety of the property.
choices.C: Identify the single point of failure in the system.

discussion.content: The goals of the BIA analysis (and by storing in Catalyst) are to determine the most crucial business functions and systems, the staff and technology resources needed for operations to run optimally, and the time frame within which the functions need to be recovered for the organization to restore operations as close as possible to a normal working state.
